TopicTitle: each manufacturer should have a bank account

Articles.Content: Starting out at x dollars. When an item of theirs is bought, the money goes in to their account. This account is used in conjunction with an algorithm to decide what parts and such they want tested. The test money is withdrawn from their account. Each part has a certain checklist of what speed and altitude it wants tested, and works these three values to find the ideal testing they want to ask you to do. I feel as if I explained this poorly but perhaps you will be able to understand what I am trying to suggest.
I get the point, but I feel this is unnecessarily complicating things. Is that adding something to the gameplay?

I don't think that's a good idea, since money then will be a finite resource ingame, and only available to those companies who sell parts. What about the Record Keeping Society, Sean's Cannery, Winterowl, ...? You then don't only have to manage your own bank account, but theirs too by buying stuff you don't need to give them money to do contracts for them again. Doesn't sound like a good idea to me.

Maybe something a bit more abstract, like a stock market graph that just breaks down who you buy most of your parts from. Like Rockomax has a 43% market share of the space industry because you buy 43% of your parts from them. But recovered parts dont count towards it since if you recover it you arnt buying a new one. It doesnt make it finite but just adds a small layer or immersion. Not really going to change gameplay so its more of a late stage polish type thing.
We don't need to turn KSP into German economical strategy game.

We don't need to turn KSP into German economical strategy game.

You aroused my curiosity. Have you a particular title in mind?

German economic strategy games are known for a quite complex economic management component, like it was with with The Settlers 1-4 (+5 maybe, made by BlueByte), the Anno series (Sunflowers), The Guild 1-2 (4HEAD Studios) and Patrician 1-4 (Ascaron). To be honest it's not a official genre name, more or less a community name honoring the mainly german heritage of the developing studios & publisher.
